text: I used options to make twenty six thousand dollars last week on the svb bank downfall and I want to walk you through the trades I made same thing I typically do for my trade management videos I want you to see why I did what I did how I managed it how I thought about the positions and so on and so forth so what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to all the outliers let's take a look at some trades so first thing we have here is the product I chose for this trade was XLF and if you know why throw it in the comments below but there is a specific reason why I chose XLF versus something else now for those that don't know if we take a look at sivb which is svb's uh ticker you'll notice that on the 9th of March we fell from 265 down to 100 and it hasn't traded since and there's a bunch of different reasons for that but long story short it was halted and not reopened so even though I wanted to trade civb I was unable to obviously because it was halted so then I decided to take a look at what else is tightly correlated to sivb and the reason why this is such an important note is even though my hypothesis was really centered on SBB and the overall hypothesis is as simple as you think it is I saw the bank failing

decided to take a look at what else is tightly correlated to sivb and the reason why this is such an important note is even though my hypothesis was really centered on SBB and the overall hypothesis is as simple as you think it is I saw the bank failing and I figured I would be able to get in and take a little bit of a ride at least until I could get out there's a lot of momentum with stuff like this and a lot of times it takes a few days to play out and I was getting in on 10 March so a lot of the news broke on nine March still developing people are still synthesizing information so I want to walk you through only two of the trades I put on I put on probably maybe close to 14 trades around this event in its entirety but I want to specifically talk about two trades so so as I saw the opportunity here I needed to find something I could trade to gain the exposure but not be just Market exposure I did end up trading broader Market exposure on Monday in the afternoon and then Tuesday Wednesday but that was kind of a follow-on hypothesis my initial hypothesis was that there would be a ton of volatility around the event and that financials would look weak so with that I started coming over here and I wanted to get an eyeball on what

day the three-day correlation is 0.996957 unbelievably high and then the correlation for a five day is 0.9196 also very high I'm looking for something 85 percent plus and then what made me like this even more was the longer term correlations I knew this was going to be a short-term trade but I wanted to see is this a new phenomenon that started to pop in or was this fairly persistent and if we take a look at the 10 day it was um 92 yeah 92 93 and then at the 30 day was 89 I didn't care so much about the 60 and 90 even though those were also very high so the main thing I'm highlighting here is that there was a lot of built-in opportunity and XLF turned out to be kind of the the primary product that I wanted trade so now what strategy am I going to use here well there's a couple things that come to mind and the first thing though is I at the time I was placed in this trade I had no idea how all of this was going to come out in the wash I had no idea so I wasn't comfortable trading short calls now in a scenario like this short calls look very attractive but the risk is not worth it to me even though you have a couple things working in your favor specifically the expansion and volatility um it's the Good short Deltas

idea so I wasn't comfortable trading short calls now in a scenario like this short calls look very attractive but the risk is not worth it to me even though you have a couple things working in your favor specifically the expansion and volatility um it's the Good short Deltas so on and so forth the other thing is I wanted to trade the velocity and you don't get that with short calls short calls have a capped Max profit so you might get the move in your favor short call payout looks something like that except this is typically flat and as the underlying moves down you hit a Max profit Zone that's not what I wanted so in this case I actually did a few things I ended up shorting XLF but it became hard to borrow and it was expensive so then I also had the long puts and I want to specifically talk about two long put strategies that I had around this I had a bunch of other things at play but this is kind of a really good example on how I like to play extreme moves like this with leverage it's why I use options and there's a specific way I structure these traits so here they are on the 10th of March XLF was trading around 33-ish it was obviously moving all over the place but uh it was around 33. and I bought to open 100 of the 17 March 34

use options and there's a specific way I structure these traits so here they are on the 10th of March XLF was trading around 33-ish it was obviously moving all over the place but uh it was around 33. and I bought to open 100 of the 17 March 34 puts at 87 cents so what this means is those were like an 88 slash a hundred Delta the Deltas were flying all over the place they were in the money obviously um but yeah they were pretty firmly in the money so it's somewhere around high 80s low 90s and at points when I saw the trade I was at a one Delta before the move this comes out to be an 8 700 outlet and then I also bought 400 of the 30 puts at seven cents as you could tell by the price here these were very low Delta 7 Delta and that's a 2800 outlay so what's going on here I'm exposing myself to two different functions of options that I'm very interested in I wait this trade because there's less risk involved and what I mean by that is since it's in the money it's going to be slightly slower in terms of theta Decay if I didn't get the move on Monday but it came Tuesday but as you can tell the trade was entered on 10 March these were only one week long so I was exposing myself obviously to a ton of

going to be slightly slower in terms of theta Decay if I didn't get the move on Monday but it came Tuesday but as you can tell the trade was entered on 10 March these were only one week long so I was exposing myself obviously to a ton of long volatility that's what I wanted to see but I needed to move quickly so by trading a higher Delta here this is very stereotypical to the way that I buy options anybody that follows the channel knows that I prefer to go further in the money it's more expensive but I start to get a dollar for dollar move faster and that's just because of the Delta so for every one dollar move in XLF in my favor um not paying attention to any changes in volatility but looking at just the Delta if XLF moves a dollar I'm getting a 88 Cent move so it's pretty close now this is the trade that is more important this is what I like to call a kicker and other options Traders call it the same thing but it's exactly what that sounds like I am putting a smaller amount of money but I'm going further out of the money why is this if you know why I'm doing this throw it in the comments below before I answer because there's two specific reasons the first reason is this is a cheap way for me to speculate and what I mean

money but I'm going further out of the money why is this if you know why I'm doing this throw it in the comments below before I answer because there's two specific reasons the first reason is this is a cheap way for me to speculate and what I mean by that is the payout on these options as you'll see in a minute pretty handsome but if you give them just a little bit of Delta meaning these aren't like a two Delta or a one Delta I actually like to Target about a 10 Delta but those were a little too overpriced so that's why I went to a seven Delta but in the scenario it's a cheap way for me to speculate heavily even if this whole thing expires worthless I'm only losing 2 800 I don't care now the other note here is in terms of the management on both of these I'll talk about that in just a second but the second reason is because of gamma if I start to get a move in my favor gamma is gonna pick up rapidly and as gamma picks up rapidly it means I get bigger and bigger Delta much more quickly this is where you get those huge compounding returns in options is when you buy something that's pretty far out of the money and it moves in your favor with velocity the payout is handsome so that is why I staggered two different trades together

bigger Delta much more quickly this is where you get those huge compounding returns in options is when you buy something that's pretty far out of the money and it moves in your favor with velocity the payout is handsome so that is why I staggered two different trades together this was all part of like the same strategy that I was running which was the long puts side of my speculation in XLF so in this case the way I'm managing this trade the trade plan here is I'm willing to lose all of this and the reason why is I acknowledge the fact that I'm trading around a highly volatile event I limit some of my systemic Risk by not trading unsystemic risk Sorry by trading the index ETF and I'm talking about things like something halting and getting stuck with an option that otherwise would be in the money but it's not in the money because it was halted and not reopened before expiration there's squirrely things like that that can happen now the way that I think about these though is it's gone this is an entire speculation amount of money it's gone and the reason why I think about it that way is if there is a big issue with liquidity or something like that you can get stuck so I didn't want to walk into this thinking oh I'm going to be able to pull you know and Salvage the trade especially on these

why I think about it that way is if there is a big issue with liquidity or something like that you can get stuck so I didn't want to walk into this thinking oh I'm going to be able to pull you know and Salvage the trade especially on these because they move fast now my ideal management plan was these were gonna I was just gonna let these go but if I saw them trade down to essentially um a thousand dollars remaining value and I wasn't getting the move I would have looked at taking them off but this is a small enough amount of money I essentially just wrote this off now this was going to be taken off at a 50 loss if I hit it and if I could but I want to make that abundantly clear when you're trading big events like this there is always the opportunity for things to not work the way that we want to work and if my entire strategy success was predicated on getting out of this at 50 it would have been a problem and the reason why it would have been a problem is if for whatever reason I was locked out then my trade falls apart so that's why I have in specifically these highly volatile style trades I'm gonna have two different points I'm gonna have whatever size I put out I am more likely than not going to allow that to be my

whatever reason I was locked out then my trade falls apart so that's why I have in specifically these highly volatile style trades I'm gonna have two different points I'm gonna have whatever size I put out I am more likely than not going to allow that to be my maximum risk and then I'm going to have my controlled risk portion whereas if I'm able to get out and I'm not seeing the conditions playing out as I thought they were I will pull the trigger and exit at that point that applies very specifically to these and this is also different than how I used to do it when I was rapidly trying to grow my account I would trade on Leverage and that essentially means you have to have risk control and you have to have the ability to get out but the other thing I was always prepared to do in those other scenarios was hedge I would have other products queued up to hedge if I couldn't get out stuff like that I wasn't looking to do all that here so that is why size was my first risk control metric and the second risk control metric was like I said um exiting 50 on these right here and then these I essentially was just going to write them out but if I saw them trading down at a thousand total value I would have exited if I could have to be clear all right

control metric was like I said um exiting 50 on these right here and then these I essentially was just going to write them out but if I saw them trading down at a thousand total value I would have exited if I could have to be clear all right so what ended up happening let's take a look real quick at XLF so this is the 10th of March and you can see the way that it ran this is the 13th so this is Monday this is actually when I got out and if you kind of think about it I got out early because I didn't deal with this day but there would have been three other great exit periods based on what I was trading nonetheless I got out and the reason why I got out on Monday is because it made my move when I was thinking about where I want this thing to go I didn't have a specific price Target because when volatility gets injected at that level it's very very difficult to pick a specific price Target especially when you're trading options because you might get to the price Target but then the options might not behaving the way you think that they should but I expected to see a pretty sizable move and I got it to some degree I actually thought I would have seen a little bit more of a move so essentially on Friday we closed at 32.93

the options might not behaving the way you think that they should but I expected to see a pretty sizable move and I got it to some degree I actually thought I would have seen a little bit more of a move so essentially on Friday we closed at 32.93 and then on Monday we opened at 3176 we hit a low of 31.37 and close at 31.63. so it wasn't like this big giant move but it was enough because I also got this beautiful implied volatility accommodation so here's what ended up happening those 34 puts so these ones right here that I bought for 87 cents or 87 per contract I sold for 232. so that comes out to be about 145 dollars per contract I had 100 contracts and this is a 167 percent return on invested Capital beautiful trade the second trade here is I sold to close these 30 puts these are the these are the cool ones because this is how options work um I bought those for seven cents sold them out for 38 cents doesn't seem like a bunch of money it's only 31 dollars per lot but again I had a bunch of them 400 contracts so that represents a 443 return on invested Capital those kind of moves obviously they always look really cool because it's like wow seven cents to 38 cents a 443 return on invested Capital what a great return and as a just return basis

a bunch of them 400 contracts so that represents a 443 return on invested Capital those kind of moves obviously they always look really cool because it's like wow seven cents to 38 cents a 443 return on invested Capital what a great return and as a just return basis that is a good return but the problem is is a lot of people unless you trade those at size really walking out with bunch of money which you'll see in a second it was okay but it wasn't you know what you might expect for something that shows up 443 return of S capital what I mean by that is I mean 14 500 on the 34 puts and I made 12 400 on the um 30 puts so it's good but it's still not as good as something that was deeper in the money and cost more money on the initial outlay but nonetheless it was a great kicker because I only had to put 2800 bucks out so this is why I really like combining these two strategies if you get a big enough accommodating move it can be very lucrative especially if you trade the low Delta options at leverage however if you don't get that move there's a high chance that this just evaporates which is why I like to tie this in because more often than not if I'm trading speculative Direction via long options I will go in the money and then something

Delta options at leverage however if you don't get that move there's a high chance that this just evaporates which is why I like to tie this in because more often than not if I'm trading speculative Direction via long options I will go in the money and then something at or out of the money and even if the out of the money options start to Decay away and they're not really doing what I need them to do fast enough the in the Money Trade typically as long as I get a little bit of accommodation they typically will at least cover the cost of the speculative outlay at least not always but that's part of the overall plan here so it came out to be in 11 500 outlay with a twenty six thousand nine hundred dollar return it's a 234 percent return on invested Capital so this overall obviously simple trade if you have any questions on it though let me know I'm happy to dive into these this is definitely different than what I typically do but this is also why I think it's so important to be Flex possible as a Trader because this isn't a place for me to trade the coverage strangle this isn't a place for me to trade ratio diagonals there are tools that fit specific circumstances and I don't write any one tool off this is another scenario let's say I wanted to trade short calls against it for

isn't a place for me to trade the coverage strangle this isn't a place for me to trade ratio diagonals there are tools that fit specific circumstances and I don't write any one tool off this is another scenario let's say I wanted to trade short calls against it for whatever reason let's say I really wanted to trade short calls I would have spread off the top I would have bought a far out of the money um long call just to cap the risk when I'm trading very volatile events like this I am very risk cautious because it's a stupid way to piss a lot of money away when you're trying to speculate so as always if you have any questions let me know throw it down in the comments below be an outlier I'll see you guys later
